RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 22nd November 2019: Trump says Phase One "potentially very close"
content:
* SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries flat, dollar up, crude down,

* REAR VIEW: Trump says China deal “potentially very close”; US PMI beats; Michigan revised higher; Lagarde avoids rocking boat.

* NEXT WEEK: MON: German IFO, New Zealand Retail Sales; TUE: German GFK Consumer Climate, Swiss Employment, US Goods Trade Balance, House Price Index, Case-Shiller House Price Index, CB Consumer Confidence, New Home Sales, Richmond Manufacturing Index, New Zealand Trade Balance, Fed Discount Rate Minutes; WED: Chinese Industrial Profit, Norwegian Unemployment Rate, US Durable Goods, Core PCE Prices, Real Consumer Spending, Pending Home Sales, Personal Spending and Consumption, GDP (2nd) and PCE Price Index, Japanese Retail Sales, Fed's Beige Book; THU: Australian CAPEX, Swiss GDP, German CPI (Prelim), EZ M3 Money Supply, Consumer Confidence, Canadian GDP, Banxico Minutes, Japanese Unemployment Rate, Industrial Production and Tokyo CPI, US Thanksgiving Market Holiday; FRI: German Import Prices, Swedish GDP, German Labour Market Report, UK M4 Money Supply, EZ CPI (Flash), Canadian GDP, Chicago PMI, CBRT Financial Stability Report, US Black Friday, US Bill Settlement, US Early Close. RANsquawk week in focus preview can be accessed here. The RANsquawk central bank weekly briefing can be accessed here.

* TRUMP: In a wide-ranging interview on Fox, US President Trump largely stuck to domestic themes centring around the Democrats impeachment inquiry. However, Trump did state that a trade deal with China was "potentially very close", and Trump reportedly told China President Xi that this "cannot be an even deal", adding that China wanted to make a deal more than the US. Trump did acknowledge that the situation in Hong Kong was a "complicating factor", though when he was asked if he would sign the Hong Kong bill, Trump said that the US "has to stand with Hong Kong, but I'm also standing with President Xi", urging both sides to 'work it out' between themselves -- it suggests that Trump might yet be undecided on whether he will sign the bill. Trump said VP Pence had done a remarkable job as Vice President, intimating that Pence will remain his running mate in the 2020 campaign. On the rumour Secretary of State Pompeo was set to leave his role in order to pursue a Senate campaign, Trump did not directly answer the question, but said Pompeo could easily win in Kansas.

* US/CHINA: In separate US/China trade related news, the majority of US’ FCC members said they would vote to designate Huawei and ZTE as national security risks, with all five members voting to ban US Government rural carrier customers from seeking federal subsidies to purchase Huawei and ZTE equipment. In other news, US has increased scrutiny of business deals involving foreign firms in 2017 and 2018, just prior to a new law that called for tougher restrictions. The article added that in the years leading up to this period (2016-2017), most foreign acquisitions had involved Chinese firms. Elsewhere, commentary from the Chinese side followed the usual rhetoric; China wants to work for a phase one trade deal with the US based on mutual respect and equality, said China’s President Xi. Additionally, Xi said the US and China should strengthen communications on strategic issues to avoid misjudgement, and added that the two nations should push bilateral relations on the right path of development. In later trade, a senior white house official was cited as stating that the 15th December tariff hikes are still due to go into effect, however, a phase one trade deal might see US President Trump make a decision to avoid implementing those tariffs as a gesture of goodwill.

* US MARKIT PMI: US Comp Flash PMI for the month of November came in at 51.9, higher than October’s reading of 50.9. Both the Manufacturing and Services subcomponents came in strong, with the former printing at 52.2 vs expectations for 51.5 and the latter coming in at 51.6 vs expectations for 51; moreover, both increased M/M. “The latest survey results are indicative of GDP rising at a modest annualised rate of just 1.5%” said IHS Markit, “with payrolls rising at a monthly clip of approximately 100,000”. On inflationary pressures, IHS noted how they remained “historically subdued” in November, with private sector firms registering only a modest increase in input prices and output charges. Finally, IHS’ Chief Economist called the latest increase in the headline indices a “welcome upturn” which “adds to evidence that the worst of the economy’s recent soft patch may be behind us.”

* UNI OF MICHIGAN FINAL: The final sentiment reading for November was revised upwards to 96.8. Wells Fargo notes that, despite the small climb, sentiment remains well below its 101.4 pre-trade war high set back in March 2018. However, “the wealth effect—the link between stocks and households’ assessment of their finances—has been on display throughout this cycle” caveats the bank, who suggest that “if the recent equity market gains hold, there could be scope for further improvement.” Conditions came in at 111.6 vs. expectations for 111.4, and above the prior 110.9 reading and Expectations came in at 87.3 vs. expectations for 86.1, up from the 85.9 prior.

* EZ PMI: The Eurozone Composite Markit PMI figure came in soft, at 50.3 vs expectations for 50.9. The headline miss was driven by weakness in Services, which came in at 51.5, below expectations for 52.5. Contrastingly, Manufacturing came in ahead of expectations for 46.4 with a reading of 46.6. "The eurozone economy remained becalmed for a third successive month in November, with the lacklustre PMI indicative of GDP growing at a quarterly rate of just 0.1%, down from 0.2% in the third quarter" IHS Markit said of the data. The slowdown in the service sector is impacting price growth, notes ING, as businesses indicate that prices charged rose at the slowest pace in three years, a reflection of weaker input costs.” For the ECB, the bank concludes, “this means that little upside to the inflation outlook can be expected in the coming months”. Germany’s Comp number came in at 49.2, slightly lower than expectations for 49.4, but a touch higher than the 48.9 prior. The bulk of the improvement came in the manufacturing sector, which rose to 43.8 from last month’s 42.1 reading, and ahead of expectations for 42.9. Services declined slightly to 51.3 from 51.6, lower than the consensus 52.0 reading. The French Comp figure improved marginally in November, rising to 52.7 form last month’s 52.6, slightly below expectations for 52.8. French manufacturing PMI came in better than the expected 50.9, printing at 51.6, while Services was slightly softer than expectations for 53 at 52.9.

* ECB’S LAGARDE: Remarks from newly appointed ECB President Lagarde did very little to rock the boat ahead of her debut meeting next month. Given the lack of unanimity on the Governing Council in recent months (which saw Sabine Lautenschlaeger step down from her position), Lagarde opted to avoid front-running the December policy decision and instead will wait until the 12th to seek consensus on the next steps forward for the Bank. The overall contents of the speech provided little in the way of surprises with the ECB’s recently adopted mantra of seeking fiscal assistance a key theme of her remarks. More specifically, Lagarde noted “it is clear that monetary policy could achieve its goal faster and with fewer side effects if other policies were supporting growth alongside it”. Elsewhere, Lagarde made a reference to a “near future” “strategic review” into monetary policy, something which is expected to be a hallmark of the initial stages of her tenure at the Bank. Interestingly, ING placed focus on one comment stating “a monetary union focused too much on risk sharing is likely to produce moral hazard and too little saving”, something that ING viewed as “a tribute to a mainly German-speaking audience”. Overall, Lagarde presented little in the way of fresh insight into what to expect for the future course of monetary policy, with the ECB President viewing the December 12th podium in Frankfurt as a more opportune time. 

* ECB: ECB’s Weidmann (Hawk) said the ECB strategy gives them leeway not to respond to every "slight" revision in the inflation outlook. Weidmann noted the first signs have emerged that the downturn in Germany's export-orientated industry could level off. On inflation, Weidmann said driving inflation above target intentionally was not consistent with strategy, while the impact of tiering on the profitability of banks was modest, though he believes that accommodative policy was still warranted; he added that he agreed with incoming ECB chief Lagarde on the need for a policy review.

* CANADIAN SEPTEMBER RETAIL SALES: Headline retail sales fell by 0.1% M/M, in line with expectations, as gasoline prices and declines in auto sales weighed. RBC notes that the latter has generally been soft this year; “while housing has clearly gotten a boost from lower interest rates, auto sales have not,” RBC writes, “that strength in housing was evident in rising sales at building material stores, which hit a record high on a volumes basis in October.” RBC says that, despite a soft end to the quarter, retail sales volumes were 1.9% higher in Q3, the strongest pace in a year. The Canadian bank expects overall consumer spending (which will be contained in next week’s GDP report) likely rose at a similar pace. “The BOC is keeping an eye on the household sector, with strength there essential to offset headwinds to investment and exports,” RBC writes, “it looks like both consumer spending and housing made solid contributions to growth last quarter.”

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (Z9) SETTLES 1 TICK LOWER AT 129-14+. The T-Plex is lower for the second consecutive week; today's losses was inspired by upside in the equity complex, with hints from US President Trump that a trade deal with China is "potentially very close". The data slate was also supportive, with a better than expected US Markit PMI, while University of Michigan consumer sentiment data was revised higher, boding well CB gauge of consumer confidence, released next week. Volumes were light, and at settlement, the curve was mixed, with the 2s through 7s higher yields, 10s roughly unchanged, while 30s yields were slightly lower; major curve spreads, however, narrowed by around 1-2bps.

* WTI (F0) SETTLES USD 0.81 LOWER AT USD 57.77/BBL; BRENT SETTLES USD 0.58 LOWER AT USD 63.39/BBL: After hitting 9-week highs on Thursday, crude fell at the end of the week with some desks citing profit taking ahead of the weekend, while punchy rhetoric on the US/China front was also cited by some traders; while macro data provided some support, it wasn't particularly significant for the crude complex. "The S&P 500 has seen some similar swings, with an initial bullish reaction to a tweet from President Trump that the US was 'potentially very close' to reaching a trade agreement with China fading, presumably because investors are tired of riding the US-China see-saw," Citi's analysts said. Citi also argues that the initial spin that an OPEC+ extension of the current supply curb agreement would prove supportive may also be fading, as more reports highlight this would fail to compensate for the projected decline in the call on OPEC crude oil for 2020.

* CLOSING LEVELS: S&P 500 0.2% at 3110, NASDAQ-100 0.1% at 8272, Dow Jones  0.4% at 27874; SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary  0.6%, Consumer Staples  -0.2%, Energy  -0.4%, Financials  0.8%, Health Care  0.4%, Industrials  0.5%, Information Technology  -0.1%, Materials  0.2%, Telecommunication Services  0.1%, Utilities  0%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Of note for Semiconductors, RBC highlighted comments from Micron’s (MU) CEO, who spoke on the DRAM market noting “What’s happening now is that the demand growth is actually greater than the supply growth. As a result, the supply and demand balance is starting to improve.” The CEO added “There is still excessive inventory in the DRAM industry and producers, but the inventory is coming down fast”. Tesla (TSLA) fell over 5% after it revealed its electric pickup truck with a starting price of USD 39,900. The truck was made from stainless steel, massive tires and armoured glass windows, resembling an armoured truck. The pricing is lower than initially thought, but the report notes its design could limit sales. CEO Musk announced other versions will be priced at USD 49,900 and USD 69,900 with the latter offering a range of more than 500 miles. Microsoft (MSFT) were granted a license from the US to export mass-market software to Huawei. Yum! Brands Inc (YUM) authorised a USD 2bln share repurchase programme through to the end of June 2021. Universal Display (OLED) were hit on a downgrade from Cowen. Elsewhere, US President Trump says his administration will come up with an age for e-cigarette purchases. On drugmakers, President Trump said he intends to fight high drug prices, and his administration will soon release a plan to allow states to import prescription drugs. L Brands (LB) reportedly mulling strategic alternatives, The Deal reported.

* EARNINGS: Nordstrom (JWN) rallied after its earnings reported a strong beat, whilst revenues were in line with estimates. Foot Locker (FL) however were hit despite an EPS beat, although revenues fell short and it forecasts its Q4 comp sales to be relatively flat. JM Smucker (SJM) EPS beat street estimates whilst revenues fell slightly short. SJM also cut its FY20 EPS and revenue forecasts, the poor guidance sent the stock lower in the pre-market before trading in the green at the open.  Splunk (SPLK) earnings report was strong, the stock rallied ~7% after EPS and revenue beats, whilst Q4 guidance was also solid, and it raised its FY20 revenue forecasts.

* M&A: Talks between Charles Schwab (SCHW) and TD Ameritrade (AMTD) reportedly hit a “technical hiccup” at board level, which has delayed an initial announcement. However, the sources noted the deal is final, but they expect the “hiccup” expects it to be overcome imminently, according to sources cited by FBN’s Gasparino. Over in Europe, Peugeot (UG FP) PSA reportedly are remained focus on Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) talks and are aiming to get an MOU signed in December, again, according to sources.

* WEEKLY FX WRAP - DXY, YUAN: Another week of conflicting trade updates and source reports with some pointing to pessimism in China, others to progress towards a deal, and a few on the US Hong Kong bill’s passage into law morphing into a wedge in talks. US President Trump spoke on Friday and stated that a US-Sino deal is “potentially very close”, but the President reportedly told his Chinese counterpart that it “cannot be an even deal”, whilst adding HK democracy is a complicating factor but refused to answer if he will sign the bill. Earlier in the day, President Xi blamed the States for starting the dispute and added that it will fight back, however the Leader took a more conciliatory approach when speaking of ways to overcome the spat. The week also saw the latest FOMC Minutes which added nothing new to the overall Fed narrative. DXY is poised to end the European week with modest gains having nursed earlier losses after printing a weekly band of 97.68-98.13, topping its 100 DMA at 98.04 amid the EZ PMI-induced EUR weakness coupled with above-forecast US PMI readings. Elsewhere, the Yuan sees a week of losses; USD/CNH heads into the European weekend near the top of its 7.0028-0535 weekly range and above its 21 WMA (7.0350) and 21 DMA (7.0255).

* EUR, GBP: A mixed weekly performance; the Single Currency looks poised to notch a second week of gains, albeit modest, but mostly on the back of USD dynamic with little pertinent EUR-specific news-flow throughout the week. Friday’s PMI figures showed a clear spill-over effect into the services sector from the manufacturing recession. Further, the subsequent GDP tracker pointed to a Q4 QQ rate of just 0.1%, down from 0.2% in Q3. Elsewhere, Lagarde’s first speech as ECB President provided little by way of fireworks; she noted of a strategic review of monetary policy in “the near future” and reaffirmed her call for fiscal policy. EUR/USD heads into the European close having clocked in a weekly parameter of 1.1047-97 and having eclipsed its 50 DMA at 1.1093 earlier in the week. For reference, next week’s docket includes German and EZ Prelim CPIs. Meanwhile, Sterling saw an early week bid amid tailwinds from last weekend’s polls suggesting an uptrend in the Conservative’s lead over Labour, with the polls showing a lead between 14-17 points across three surveys. However, the pair lost impetus news flow slowed down and as the pair took out multiple stops at psych levels. Further, UK’s Flash PMI debut missed expectations across the board and showed Services tipping over the fence into contraction. IHS noted the data points to a 0.2% drop in GDP in Q4, which would usually be associated with BoE stimulus, although Central Bank downplayed PMI importance at its latest MPR. Cable is set to end the EU week at the bottom of its current 1.2850-1.2985, with Friday’s mid-day downside attributed to potential stops taken out at 1.2875 which also coincides with its 21 DMA.

* JPY, CHF: The Japanese currency is set to end the EU week a tad firmer following a volatile few sessions on contrasting trade headlines/sentiment. On the domestic front, Japanese Nationwide CPI remained steady vs. expectations for a slight pickup, although the JPY was unfazed, the metric continues to pile on pressure on the BoJ to keep its momentum towards achieving its inflation goal of 2%. USD/JPY looks to end European day and week in the red and around the middle of its 108.28-109.07 weekly band, having tested its 50 WMA (109.06) earlier. Conversely, the CHF heads into the EU close on the backfoot with little by way of any fundamental catalysts, although SNB market presence cannot be ruled out given recent rhetoric from Central Bank members. EUR/CHF looks to end the week at the top of its weekly range (1.0930-1.1010) having surpassed its 21 WMA at 1.0960. Meanwhile, USD/CHF took out its 21 and 50 WMAs to the upside at 0.9876 and 0.9938, having notched an intra-week band of 0.9868-0.9950, with the top-end coinciding with its 200 DMA.

* AUD, NZD, CAD: The Antipodean look set to end the week mixed with outperformance in the Kiwi, possibly still supported by an unwind in shorts after the RBNZ left its OCR untouched last week, whilst technical factors via the AUD/NZD cross could’ve also played a part. NZD/USD looks set to end the European week towards the top of its 0.6398-0.6425 weekly band having after briefly tested its 100 WMA (0.6425) at the back end of the week on AUD/NZD dynamics as the cross fell below its 21 WMA (1.0627, 100 DMA (1.0620) and the 1.0600 mark. Meanwhile, AUD has been relatively unreactive to China-US headlines this week given the slightly muddled narrative this week. AUD/USD fell further below its 50 WMA (0.6971) and DMA (0.6810) having clocked a weekly range of 0.6780-6835 range. Looking ahead, next week’s calendar sees Kiwi retail sales, trade balance and the RBNZ Financial Stability Report whilst the Aussie calendar looks, light although RBA Governor Lowe’s speech may garner attention for an updated view on the Aussie economy. Finally, the Loonie was subdued at the front end of the week following comments from BoC First Deputy Governor Wilkins who believed that there is still room to manoeuvre on policy, comments that were leaned back on by Governor Poloz as he noted monetary conditions are “about right” given the environment. USD/CAD rose from a weekly base at 1.3190 (21 WMA) to a high of 1.3375 on Wilkins-induced CAD weakness before paring the half the move with aid from the BoC Governor. The pair looks to end the European week modestly in the green and below its 50 WMA at 1.3283.

AUD, NZD, CAD

The Antipodean look set to end the week mixed with outperformance in the Kiwi, possibly still supported by an unwind in shorts after the RBNZ left its OCR untouched last week, whilst technical factors via the AUD/NZD cross could’ve also played a part. NZD/USD looks set to end the European week towards the top of its 0.6398-0.6425 weekly band having after briefly tested its 100 WMA (0.6425) at the back end of the week on AUD/NZD dynamics as the cross fell below its 21 WMA (1.0627, 100 DMA (1.0620) and the 1.0600 mark. Meanwhile, AUD has been relatively unreactive to China-US headlines this week given the slightly muddled narrative this week. AUD/USD fell further below its 50 WMA (0.6971) and DMA (0.6810) having clocked a weekly range of 0.6780-6835 range. Looking ahead, next week’s calendar sees Kiwi retail sales, trade balance and the RBNZ Financial Stability Report whilst the Aussie calendar looks, light although RBA Governor Lowe’s speech may garner attention for an updated view on the Aussie economy. Finally, the Loonie was subdued at the front end of the week following comments from BoC First Deputy Governor Wilkins who believed that there is still room to manoeuvre on policy, comments that were leaned back on by Governor Poloz as he noted monetary conditions are “about right” given the environment. USD/CAD rose from a weekly base at 1.3190 (21 WMA) to a high of 1.3375 on Wilkins-induced CAD weakness before paring the half the move with aid from the BoC Governor. The pair looks to end the European week modestly in the green and below its 50 WMA at 1.3283.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 22nd November 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • EZ PMIs were mixed with manufacturing beat but services subdued, UK missed across the board
  • European bourses are slightly firmer this morning on little in the way of trade updates and mixed data
  • ECB’s Lagarde speech delivered little in the way of surpises for markets
  • DXY is flirting with the 98.0 mark to the upside, with G10 peers mixed and the core debt complex firmer
  • US President Trump signed the continuing resolution to avert a government shutdown to December 20th
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Flash Markit PMIs; US University of Michigan Sentiment, Baker Hughes Rig Count, G20 Finance Ministers Meeting in Japan
  • Speakers: ECB’s de Guindos, Riksbank’s Ohlsson & Jansson

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets eventually traded mixed after the region’s early attempts to shrug-off the headwinds from the losses on Wall St. proved to be short-lived, as trade uncertainty remained the state of play. ASX 200 (+0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.3%) were higher with outperformance in Australia’s tech and energy sectors prevailing over the lacklustre tone in financials and weakness in gold miners, while Japanese exporters coat-tailed on the gradual upside seen in USD/JPY and with SoftBank mildly benefitting from reports the Co. is in discussions to reduce the WeWork offer and payout to its founder. Hang Seng (+0.5%) and Shanghai Comp.(-0.6%) initially conformed to the improved risk appetite after some of the recent trade rhetoric added to cautious optimism including comments from MOFCOM that they will strive to reach a phase one deal and after source reports suggested the US may delay the December 15th tariffs even if a trade pact is not reached. However, the mainland gradually deteriorated due to the lack of trade clarity and with the recent freedom of navigation operations by the US in the South China Sea also irking China, while Hong Kong kept afloat with the city set to proceed with local elections on Sunday. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower amid spill over selling from USTs, with prices also weighed by the somewhat improved risk appetite and following weaker demand at the enhanced liquidity auction for longer-dated JGBs.

PBoC skips open market operations for a net weekly injection of CNY 300bln vs. net neutral position last week. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0306 vs. Exp. 7.0314 (Prev. 7.0217)

Chinese President Xi said China did not start the trade dispute with US and is not afraid of a trade war, nor will it flinch from such a fight but added he wants to work out a phase one agreement with US on basis of respect and equality. Furthermore, Xi added we will fight back when necessary but have been working actively to try to not have a trade war. (Newswires)

Chinese President Xi says US and China should strengthen communication on strategic issues to avoid misjudgment, adding that the two nations should push bilateral relations on the right path of development. (Newswires)

Microsoft (MSFT) announced it received a license on November 20th to export mass-market software to Huawei. (Newswires/SCMP)

Hong Kong Police Chief said high profile patrols will be deployed for elections this Sunday and urged protesters not to resort to violence, while he added there is no deadline set for the campus clearance and wants a peaceful resolution. (Newswires)

Japanese National CPI (Oct) Y/Y 0.2% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. 0.2%). (Newswires) Japanese National CPI Ex. Fresh Food (Oct) Y/Y 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.4% (Prev. 0.3%) Japanese National CPI Ex. Fresh Food & Energy (Oct) Y/Y 0.7% vs. Exp. 0.6% (Prev. 0.5%)

US

US President Trump signed the continuing resolution to avert a shutdown and fund government agencies through to December 20th as expected. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson's Conservatives pledged an additional 3% levy on property purchases by non-UK tax residents. (Newswires)

Dame Helena Morrissey appeared to rule herself out as a candidate to be the first ever female governor of the Bank of England after agreeing to go on to the board of St James’s Place yesterday. (Times)

UK Flash Services PMI (Nov) 48.6 vs. Exp. 50 (Prev. 50)

- UK Flash Manufacturing PMI (Nov) 48.3 vs. Exp. 49 (Prev. 49.6)

- UK Flash Composite PMI (Nov) 48.5 (Prev. 50)

- "The weak survey data puts the economy on course for a 0.2% drop in GDP in the fourth quarter, and also pushes the PMI further into territory that would normally be associated with the Bank of England adding more stimulus to the economy. -IHS Markit

ECB President Lagarde says monetary policy could achieve its goal faster and with fewer side effects if other policies were supporting growth alongside it. Monetary policy will continue to support the economy and respond to future risks in-line with our price stability mandate, we will continuously monitor side effects of policies; adds, monetary policy will undergo a strategic review due to begin in the near future. (Newswires)

- "The eurozone economy remained becalmed for a third successive month in November, with the lacklustre PMI indicative of GDP growing at a quarterly rate of just 0.1%, down from 0.2% in the third quarter." - IHS Markit

EQUITIES

Major European bourses (Euro Stoxx 50 +0.2%) are modestly firmer, with the bulk of the gains coming right after the European cash open, before the indices proceeded to give back some gains following downbeat EZ PMI data, which saw manufacturing beat expectations but raised some concerns over the health of the larger services sector. Elsewhere, a speech by ECB President Lagarde failed to deliver much by way of a bang, while the pace of updates on the trade front also appears to have slowed down somewhat, giving equity markets a breather from the prior day’s whipsaw action. Most notably, the news of further freedom of navigation operations by the US in the South China Sea, nor the news of the Trump Administration mulling alternative trade investigations against the EU appears to have changed the dial much. Sectors are all in the green; energy (+0.7%) and materials (+0.6%) are for now the outperformers, while Utilities (+0.3%) and Consumer Staples (+0.3%) lag. In terms of the notable stock movers; Edenred (-2.2%) are at the bottom of the Stoxx 600 table after the Co. stated that it is still investigating the extent of a malware infection and has contacted relevant government authorities and regulators. Elsewhere, Wirecard (-0.1%) nursed earlier losses after Uber (UBER) denied reports that it was considering hiring Wirecard as its main payments partner.

GEOPOLITICS

US Navy warships conducted 2 freedom of navigation operations in the South China Sea earlier this week, while China’s military later stated its navy tracked US ships that sailed near islands claimed by China in the South China Sea, while it urged US to stop provocative actions. (Newswires) Subsequently, China's Foreign Ministry has lodged stern representation with US after US ships sailed in South China Sea near islands claimed by China. (Newswires)

South Korean Finance Minister will be visiting Japan ahead of the expiry of the South Korean-Japanese Military Information Agreement, according to sources cited by Yonhap. Subsequently, South Korea told Japan it will extend the General Security of Military Information Agreement (GSOMIA) intel-sharing pact, according to NHK; however, Japan says there are no changes to export restrictions on materials for South Korea, according to Japanese trade official. (Newswires)

Iran is holding "massive air defence drills" over the Persian Gulf and the strategic Strait of Hormuz, according to Tasnim News. (Twitter)

FX

EUR, GBP - Both softer with the Single Currency subdued in wake of the EZ PMIs which show a clear spillover effect into the services sector from the manufacturing recession, thus negatively effects domestic demand. Services and Composite missed, and Manufacturing showed a mild bounce, but remain damped (albeit participants may have expended more of a rebound given the French and German metrics). Further, the GDP tracker pointed to a Q4 QQ rate of just 0.1%, down from 0.2% in Q3. Elsewhere, Lagarde’s first speech as ECB President was far from a fanfare release; she noted of a strategic review of monetary policy policy in “the near future” and reaffirmed her call for fiscal policy. EUR/USD took its cue from the PMIs and currently resides towards the bottom of its 1.1048-87 band (just above its 10 DMA at 1.1047) having earlier eclipsed its 100 DMA at 1.1085 on the initial French and German manufacturing bounce backs. The pair now eyes around EUR 1bln of options expiring at strikes 1.1040-60, although the next notable tranche could also come into play in later trade (EUR 1.3bln between 1.1075-90).  Similarly, UK’s Flash PMI debut missed expectations across the board and showed Services tipping over the fence into contraction. Further, IHS noted the data points to a 0.2% drop in GDP in Q4, which would usually be associated with BoE stimulus, albeit the Central Bank did downplay the credence it gives to this release at its latest MPR. Cable resides at the bottom the current 1.2873-2927 intraday parameter.

DXY, Yuan - DXY has reversed overnight losses, albeit more on EUR weakness as there is little by way of new substance on the US-Sino trade front. President Xi overnight sang from the same hymn sheet as Chinese officials, highlighting that China is not afraid of trade conflict but will actively try to avoid a trade war and called on increased communication. DXY is comfortably in the green in having surpassed 98.00 to the upside and attempted multiple breaches of its 100 DMA at 98.04 with no success. USD/CNH remains firmer, although mostly on the back of a stronger Dollar with the pair at session highs and eyeing its 100 DMA (7.0441) vs. an intraday low of 7.0264.

JPY, CHF - Safe-haven FX trade relatively flat in early hours, potentially as overall downbeat EZ PMI counter the positive geopolitical developments in Japan-South Korea relations, with the latter two agreeing to extend its intelligence-sharing pact which was due to be eradicated amid their deteriorating bond. USD/JPY meanders 108.50 and remains near the bottom of a tight 108.50-70 range. The Franc meanwhile sees downside bias, with EUR/CHF just under 1.1000 having early briefly breached the mark after clocking a 1.0980-1.1010 daily band thus far.

AUD, NZD - Both modestly firmer albeit off highs with the Kiwi outperforming its Aussie counterpart, which seems more of a technical move as AUD/NZD fell through 1.0600, with traders on the lookout for any pertinent US-Sino trade headlines for impetus.

FX Expiries, NY Cut:

- EUR/USD: 1.1040-60 (1BLN), 1.1075-90 (1.3BLN), 1.1100-10 (1.1BLN)

- AUD/USD: 0.6785 (330M), 0.6795 (1.1BLN), 0.6900 (500M)

FIXED INCOME

Government bonds are modestly firmer with Gilts currently leading the upside as they rounded off this data deluge. UK debt took a significant boost from the UK PMI metrics, which were the first flash readings for the UK, all missing on expectations, though it is worth caveating that BoE’s Carney has downplayed the importance of PMIs. Prior to this, the morning’s EZ metrics began with France where manufacturing convincingly beat as did the German and EZ wide figures albeit the latter two’s manufacturing sector remains in contractionary territory. ING note that growth is slowing significantly in Q4 which is largely due to the knock-on effects of the manufacturing recession to services, illustrated via all services prints missing on expectations this morning. In terms of reaction, the French manufacturing numbers knocked debt the most, although this has since reversed with Bunds at the top of session boundaries and comfortably above the 171.0 mark, with resistance at 171.35 ahead. The German release was partially sidelined as it coincided with remarks via ECB’s Lagarde, although these weren’t particularly ground-breaking, in-line with expectations given she has only just taken the helm and is yet to conduct a policy meeting; additionally, she did repeat familiar language calling for other policy help and that monetary policy will undergo a strategic review soon. In contrast to yesterdays outperformance, BTPs are the clear laggard at present, potentially retreating on the resurfacing of Italian political tensions as Di Maio’s 5SM members rejected his call to pause on upcoming regional elections until March. Looking ahead, as it is PMI day we will see US metrics later alongside further ECB speak to round off a relatively quiet week; ahead of US participants treasuries are mirroring the movement of EZ peers, although not quite as pronounced, while the curve is very modestly bull-flattening

COMMODITIES                                      

Crude markets are mixed but off lows in consolidative Friday morning trade, after ECB President Lagarde’s speech and mixed EZ PMI data failed to give direction to broader macro sentiment, and amidst a lack of fresh crude specific fundamental drivers. WTI Dec’ 19 futures are languishing below the USD 58.50/bbl mark, off overnight lows around USD 58.10/bbl. Brent Jan’ 20 futures meanwhile have made slightly better progress from USD 63.50/bbl overnight lows, coming within a whisker of yesterday’s high just above the USD 64.00/bbl level. In terms of the metals; gold has been on the front foot, with upside seen alongside European bonds after EZ PMI data raised concerns about service sector weakness despite a stronger than expected recovery in manufacturing. The precious metal managed to reclaim USD 1470/oz to the upside, ahead of yesterday’s USD 1476/oz high. Meanwhile, copper has also seen upside since the European open; given its status as an industrial metal, better than expected EZ manufacturing PMI results may be providing some support, while there has also been positive news on the South Korea/Japan trade front – both important industrial hubs and consumers of the red metal.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

22nd November 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the   overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets eventually traded mixed after the region’s early attempts to shrug-off the headwinds from the losses on Wall St. proved to be short-lived, as trade uncertainty remained the state of play. ASX 200 (+0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) were higher with outperformance in Australia’s tech and energy sectors prevailing over the lacklustre tone in financials and weakness in gold miners, while Japanese exporters coat-tailed on the gradual upside seen in USD/JPY and with SoftBank mildly benefitting from reports the Co. is in discussions to reduce the WeWork offer and payout to its founder. Hang Seng (+0.2%) and Shanghai Comp.(-0.6%) initially conformed to the improved risk appetite after some of the recent trade rhetoric added to cautious optimism including comments from MOFCOM that they will strive to reach a phase one deal and after source reports suggested the US may delay the December 15th tariffs even if a trade pact is not reached. However, the mainland gradually deteriorated due to the lack of trade clarity and with the recent freedom of navigation operations by the US in the South China Sea also irking China, while Hong Kong kept afloat with the city set to proceed with local elections on Sunday.

TRADE

US President Trump’s administration is reportedly mulling a trade investigation against the EU as time for imposing auto tariffs is limited, according to Politico citing people briefed on the matter. (Politico)

FTSE 100

Unilever (ULVR LN)/ Henkel (HEN GY) – Cos and Colgate-Palmolive (CL) are reportedly mulling a bid for Coty’s (COTY) Hair and Beauty brands portfolio valued at up to USD 7bln, sources state. (Newswires)

Tesco (TSCO LN) – S&P downgraded Co’s rating to “BBB-“ from “BB+”, outlook cut to “Stable” from “Positive”. (Newswires)

Housing Names – UK Conservative Party are planning on implementing a stamp duty hike for foreign buyers of property in England. (BBC/Sky News)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Daily Mail (DMGT LN) – Daily Mirror’s owner Reach has decided not to continue with the purchase of JPI Media press; DMGT are in discussions to purchase ‘i’ the only national newspaper owned by JPI Media. (Telegraph)

BROKER MOVES

AVIVA (AV/ LN) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM OVERWEIGHT AT JPMORGAN CHASE

TULLOW OIL (TLW LN) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM BUY AT CITIGROUP

DAX

Wirecard (WDI GY) – Uber (UBER) has denied reports that it was considering hiring Wirecard as its main payments partner. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

DAIMLER (DAI GY) REITERATED WITH OUTPERFORM AT RBC

ALLIANZ (ALV GY) LISTED AS PREFERRED STOCK AMONG EUROPEAN PEERS AT JPMORGAN CHASE

CAC

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Edenred (EDEN FP) – Co. stated that it is still investigating the extent of a malware infection and has contacted relevant government authorities and regulators. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

AXA (CS FP) LISTED AS PREFERRED STOCK AMONG EUROPEAN PEERS AT JPMORGAN CHASE

PAN EUROPE

Mediaset (MS IM) – Vivendi (VIV FP) said it is ready to agree to sell Mediaset shares held by Simon Fiduciaria Trustee at EUR 3.25/shr, according to source. (Newswires) For reference, Mediaset shares closed at EUR 2.68/shr on Thursday.

BROKER MOVES

POSTE ITALIANE (PST IM) LISTED AS PREFERRED STOCK AMONG EUROPEAN PEERS AT JPMORGAN CHASE

SMI

Roche (ROG SW) – Co. announced extension for shares of Spark Therapeutics, all terms and conditions of offer shall remain unchanged during extended period. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

ZURICH INSURANCE (ZURN SW) LISTED AS PREFERRED STOCK AMONG EUROPEAN PEERS AT JPMORGAN CHASE

SCANDINAVIA

BROKER MOVES

A.P. MOLLER-MAERSK (MARSKB DC) DOWNGRADED TO HOLD FROM BUY AT BERENBERG

content:

  • Asian equity markets eventually traded mixed after the region’s early attempts to shrug-off the headwinds from the losses on Wall St. proved to be short-lived
  • Chinese President Xi said China did not start the trade dispute with US and is not afraid of a trade war, nor will it flinch from such a fight but added he wants to work out a phase one agreement
  • US President Trump's administration is reportedly mulling a trade investigation against the EU as time for imposing auto tariffs is limited, according to Politico
  • Looking ahead, highlights include EZ, UK and US Flash Markit PMIs; German GDP (Detailed); US Uni of Michigan Sentiment, Baker Hughes Rig Count, G20 Finance Ministers Meeting in Japan
  • Speakers: ECB’s Lagarde, de Guindos, Riksbank’s Ohlsson, Jansson

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets eventually traded mixed after the region’s early attempts to shrug-off the headwinds from the losses on Wall St. proved to be short-lived, as trade uncertainty remained the state of play. ASX 200 (+0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) were higher with outperformance in Australia’s tech and energy sectors prevailing over the lacklustre tone in financials and weakness in gold miners, while Japanese exporters coat-tailed on the gradual upside seen in USD/JPY and with SoftBank mildly benefitting from reports the Co. is in discussions to reduce the WeWork offer and payout to its founder. However, the mainland gradually deteriorated due to the lack of trade clarity and with the recent freedom of navigation operations by the US in the South China Sea also irking China, while Hong Kong kept afloat with the city set to proceed with local elections on Sunday. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower amid spill over selling from USTs, with prices also weighed by the somewhat improved risk appetite and following weaker demand at the enhanced liquidity auction for longer-dated JGBs.

PBoC skips open market operations for a net weekly injection of CNY 300bln vs. net neutral position last week. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0306 vs. Exp. 7.0314 (Prev. 7.0217)

Chinese President Xi said China did not start the trade dispute with US and is not afraid of a trade war, nor will it flinch from such a fight but added he wants to work out a phase one agreement with US on basis of respect and equality. Furthermore, Xi added we will fight back when necessary but have been working actively to try to not have a trade war. (Newswires)

15 US Senators reportedly called on US President Trump to halt Huawei license approvals to US companies who conduct business with the Chinese telecom giant, according to reports citing a letter. In related news, Microsoft announced it received a license on November 20th to export mass-market software to Huawei. (Newswires/SCMP)

Hong Kong Police Chief said high profile patrols will be deployed for elections this Sunday and urged protesters not to resort to violence, while he added there is no deadline set for the campus clearance and wants a peaceful resolution. (Newswires)

Japanese National CPI (Oct) Y/Y 0.2% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. 0.2%). (Newswires) Japanese National CPI Ex. Fresh Food (Oct) Y/Y 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.4% (Prev. 0.3%) Japanese National CPI Ex. Fresh Food & Energy (Oct) Y/Y 0.7% vs. Exp. 0.6% (Prev. 0.5%)

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson's Conservatives pledged an additional 3% levy on property purchases by non-UK tax residents. (Newswires)

Dame Helena Morrissey appeared to rule herself out as a candidate to be the first ever female governor of the Bank of England after agreeing to go on to the board of St James’s Place yesterday. (Times)

ECB's De Guindos said risks to the EU economy are on the downside and that he is convinced the possibility of a recession is very small which he calls an unlikely event, while he also highlighted the importance of fiscal policy increasing its role. (Newswires)

US President Trump's administration is reportedly mulling a trade investigation against the EU as time for imposing auto tariffs is limited, according to Politico citing people briefed on the matter. (Politico)

FX

DXY was softer as it marginally pulled back from the 98.00 level to retrace some yesterday’s gains which were spurred by some of the positive-leaning US-China trade headlines, while its transatlantic counterparts partially nursed losses in which EUR/USD and GBP/USD rebounded from this week’s support around the 1.1050 and 1.2900 levels respectively. Elsewhere, USD/JPY was kept afloat amid the slight improvement in risk sentiment and CAD remained firmer after the recent strength in oil prices, as well as comments from BoC Governor Poloz, while antipodeans traded subdued due to a lack of tier-1 data, flimsy risk appetite and following a weaker reference rate setting from the PBoC.

COMMODITIES

Commodities traded mixed with a slight pullback in oil prices amid the indecisive risk appetite brought on by ongoing trade uncertainty, although WTI crude futures have retained the USD 58.00/bbl level and the majority of the prior day’s extended advances helped by recent source reports that OPEC+ is likely to extend its existing production cut agreement until June 2020. Elsewhere, gold remained despondent after its recent losses and failed to benefit from the mild pullback in USD, while copper was also restricted by the overnight indecision. 

GEOPOLITICS

US Navy warships conducted 2 freedom of navigation operations in the South China Sea earlier this week, while China’s military later stated its navy tracked US ships that sailed near islands claimed by China in the South China Sea, while it urged US to stop provocative actions. (Newswires)

US President Trump tweeted that Iran has become "so unstable", citing Iranians as being oppressed by the government blocking internet access and stopping news spreading of violence in Iran. (Twitter)

US

The Treasury curve flattening found some pause on Thursday, where the T-note drifted lower throughout the session. Treasury market participants were cautiously more optimistic about the state of the US-China trade updates, as was Chinese Vice Premier Liu He, where it was also reported the US had been invited to Beijing for further talks. The TPLEX failed to catch a bid on the Hong Kong bill pessimism and the whole curve was approximately 3.5bps higher by settlement. Elsewhere, the US sold USD 12bln in 10-year TIPS at a high yield of 0.149%, stopping through the WI by 0.3bps with decent domestic demand. US T-note (Z9) futures settled 10 ticks lower at 129.15+.

US stopgap bill to fund the government advanced in the Senate with lawmakers voting 75-19 to invoke cloture, or limit debate on the House passed continuing resolution, while US President Trump later signed the continuing resolution to avert a shutdown and fund government agencies through to December 20th as expected. (Newswires)

Senior White House officials and Senate Republicans agreed that a full trial should be conducted if the House impeaches President Trump according to reports citing multiple people familiar with the matter. (Politico)

US House Speaker Pelosi said made progress on USMCA trade agreement with USTR Lighthizer, while there were also comments from House Ways and Means Chair Neal that there was no deal on USMCA following the meeting although he noted a House vote is still possible by the end of 2019 and that progress has been made on the enforcement issue. (Newswires)

subject: ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Asia stocks traded mixed amid continued lack of trade clarity
content: Asia equity markets eventually traded mixed after the region’s early attempts to shrug-off the headwinds from the losses on Wall St. proved to be short-lived, as trade uncertainty remained the state of play. ASX 200 (+0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) were higher with outperformance in Australia’s tech and energy sectors prevailing over the lacklustre tone in financials and weakness in gold miners, while Japanese exporters coat-tailed on the gradual upside seen in USD/JPY and with SoftBank mildly benefitting from reports the Co. is in discussions to reduce the WeWork offer and payout to its founder. Hang Seng (+0.2%) and Shanghai Comp.(-0.6%) initially conformed to the improved risk appetite after some of the recent trade rhetoric added to cautious optimism including comments from MOFCOM that they will strive to reach a phase one deal and after source reports suggested the US may delay the December 15th tariffs even if a trade pact is not reached. However, the mainland gradually deteriorated due to the lack of trade clarity and with the recent freedom of navigation operations by the US in the South China Sea also irking China, while Hong Kong kept afloat with the city set to proceed with local elections on Sunday. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower amid spill over selling from USTs, with prices also weighed by the somewhat improved risk appetite and following weaker demand at the enhanced liquidity auction for longer-dated JGBs.

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia trades mostly higher as some of the more positive-leaning trade rhetoric adds to the cautious optimism
content:
Asia equity markets are mostly higher as the region shrugs-off the headwinds from the lacklustre performance on Wall St, but with gains limited as trade uncertainty remains the state of play. ASX 200 (+0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) are higher with tech and energy leading the broad gains across Australia’s sectors aside from gold miners after further losses in the precious metal, while Japanese exporters coat-tail on the gradual upside seen in USD/JPY with SoftBank also mildly benefitting from reports the Co. is in discussions to reduce the WeWork offer and payout to its founder. Hang Seng (+0.3%) and Shanghai Comp.(+0.2%) conform to the improved risk appetite as some of the recent trade rhetoric adds to cautious optimism including comments from MOFCOM that they will strive to reach a phase one deal and after source reports suggested the US may delay the December 15th tariffs even if a trade pact is not reached, while Hong Kong is also kept afloat with the city set to proceed with local elections on Sunday.

In FX markets, the DXY is softer as it marginally pulls back from the 98.00 level and retraces some yesterday’s gains which were spurred by some of the positive-leaning US-China trade headlines, while its transatlantic counterparts partially nurse losses with EUR/USD and GBP/USD rebounding from this week’s support around the 1.1050 and 1.2900 levels respectively. Elsewhere, USD/JPY is kept afloat amid the improvement in risk sentiment and CAD remains firmer after comments from BoC Governor Poloz suggested monetary conditions are about right which was at a slight contrast to recent suggestions by BoC's Wilkins that there is still policy room to manoeuvre, while antipodeans are subdued due to a lack of tier-1 data and with upward pressure from the improved risk tone counterbalanced by a weaker reference rate setting from the PBoC.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are lower amid spill over selling from USTs, with prices also weighed by the improved risk appetite and as participants await the enhanced liquidity auction for longer-dated JGBs.

(Newswires)

Huawei - 15 US Senators reportedly called on US President Trump to halt Huawei license approvals to US companies who conduct business with the Chinese telecom giant, according to reports citing a letter. In related news, Microsoft (MSFT) said it received license on November 20th to export mass-market software to Huawei. (Newswires/SCMP)

Casino Names - Macau October visitor arrivals rose 1.8% Y/Y to 3.21mln and which is higher than the prior month of 2.76mln visitors. (Newswires)

Trade

Chinese Commerce Ministry said they will strive to reach a phase-one trade deal with the US and that teams will maintain communication, while it noted outside rumours are not accurate regarding possible disagreements in discussions which refers to agricultural purchases, tariff removal and the timeline for a deal. (Newswires)

US may delay the December 15th tariffs if trade pact is not reached by then according to Chinese press reports citing sources, with the deal said to be on the "doorstep" but Phase One tariff removal is holding up the talks. Furthermore, it noted hopes remain a watered-down deal can be reached before the new US tariffs come into effect on December 15th. (SCMP)

China is reportedly watching US President Trump’s response to Hong Kong bill as it threatens to become another obstacle to a trade deal between the US and China, while a source suggested Beijing may decide to fight and talk alternatively and is monitoring President Trump's next move. (SCMP)

China last week invited US trade negotiators for further talks in which Chinese Vice Premier Liu He invited USTR Lighthizer and Treasury Secretary Mnuchin to hold the meeting in Beijing during a phone call late last week, according to sources. Furthermore, US negotiators said they would be willing to meet in person but would be reluctant travel all the way to China unless they make it clear that it would make commitments on IP protection, forced technology transfers and ag purchases, while Chinese officials hope the in-person negotiations can happen before next Thursday (which is the Thanksgiving holiday in the US) but the US has reportedly not committed to a date yet. (WSJ)

China is resisting US requests to guarantee agriculture purchases and reportedly "balks" at stronger language on IP and tech transfers without a guarantee on tariff rollback, while US doesn't want to agree to move until they get Chinese commitment, according to WSJ's Wei. (Twitter)

China Global Times Editor tweeted "The US has the upper hand in US-China trade war, which allows it to decide when to end the trade war, but far from enough for it to decide how to end the trade war. The US side wants both, then it needs to change an adversary". (Twitter)
